Celebrating #Juneteenth and my father‚Äôs legacy on Father's Day is an acknowledgement of the long struggle of Black men in this country. 

His resilience is the story of Black America. 8/

After World War II, the US Postal Service was one of the few public sector jobs that employed African Americans.

My father became a proud union-member letter carrier for 37 years and provided for our entire family. 7/

He was a member of the Coast Guard and was assigned to one of the first integrated units, but opted to return to the all-Black unit because of the racism he experienced.

He was proud to be one of a few Black Coast Guardsman invited to meet with First Lady Eleanor Roosevelt. 6/
He was an athlete and should have played professionally but was born a few years too early, before teams accepted Black players. 5/

My father never wanted me to enter politics because he was concerned for my safety and he thought it was too dangerous. 

He did not live to see me safely and successfully run for office. 4/

My father was from Texas and like many of his generation, he rarely spoke about what he experienced. I think it was too painful to share.

I understood later that my dad, my grandparents, and great-grandparents shouldered the legacy of slavery and institutional racism. 3/

My father didn‚Äôt realize that his daily conversations with me would shape my life.

Listening to him and watching the world change so rapidly led me to devote my life to continuing the fight for social and economic justice.

That's why today's dual celebration is so important. 2/

Pops meant the world to me. üßµ

When I was in elementary school, I watched the civil rights movement unfold on the nightly news with my dad. He explained why hundreds of thousands of people were protesting for equal rights and to end Jim Crow segregation. 1/
